subject: Off to Worldcon
event:
It has been an interesting few days, to say the least.  I never dreamed my posts here would get such an overwhelming response.  Thanks for all the comments, pro and con.  I appreciate the support, and even the thoughtful and reasoned responses from many who disagree with me.  As for the handful who chose to chant cant or throw insults... you should be ashamed of yourselves.

No politics this time.  I'm packing right now.  Tomorrow morning I'm off, first to Albuquerque for Bubonicon, our friendly little local convention, and then on Monday to LA for worldcon.  Let us all hope that no new crisis intervenes, so that I am allowed to board the airplane.  I will try to resist the urge to go "baaaaa, baaaaaa, baaaaaa" as I pass through the metal detector.

I love worldcon, and this year should be a good one.  Aside from being in Anaheim (not my favorite part of LA), the convention facility is a great one, really well set up for parties, and the Brotherhood Without Banners is promising to pull out all the stops this time around.  

On other fronts, I should mention that we have just added a new stop to my ICE DRAGON promotional schedule.  On Tuesday, September 26, I will be signing at the River Lights Bookstore in Dubuque, Iowa.  Full details will soon be posted to the Appearances page on my website.  I lived in Dubuque for three years (1976 - 1979)a long, long, long time ago, but have only been back there once in the last twenty-six years, and that only briefly, so I am looking forward to seeing my old haunts again.  I hope the place hasn't changed as much as my old neighborhood in Chicago had when I went back there in May.

And to appease all those who come to my site mainly for updates about A DANCE WITH DRAGONS... sorry, guys, you're not going to like this news any more than I do, but the last month has been a washout as far as writing is concerned.  My home renovations have been very distracting, all sorts of other things have been breaking or demanding my attention, there were tax records to prepare for my accountant (I had to take an extension last April), and it seems as if every day has been full of crises and interruptions.  I do hope the worst is behind me, however, and that I can plunge back into the book when I get back from LA.  I need to make certain that September is a more productive month than August.    

I do intend to continue to speak out on political issues from time to time, but perhaps not at such length as I have these past few days.  It has been fun, and invigorating, and even enlightening in parts, but it takes time and energy, and just now I need to save most of my time and energy for A DANCE WITH DRAGONS and WILD CARDS and my myriad other publishing projects, old and new.

comments.article:
Hi George. I didn't post any comments on the last two entries because I didn't have anything to say that hasn't been said already by the time I saw the entries. At any rate, I just want to say that as far as I'm concerned, someone who is engaged in the real world is more worthy of respect than a recluse who simply types out manuscript pages. So kudos for staying engaged and sharing your thoughts. The book will be done when it'll be done, is my thinking. I want to find out what happens next, of course, but another month or two of waiting isn't going to shatter my world.

Plus, it is summer. So there.

Have a good trip out. The BwB people are all psyched for the Con. I won't be in LA, but I'm hoping I'll catch you on the midwest tour later, either at ArchCon or at Dubuque*.



*Incidentally, my partner and I drive down to various parts of IA around Dubuque for family events regularly, and every time we pass Galina I always thought of [u]Fevre Dream[/u] and steamboats and vampires.
If you need a ride to Dubuque let me know... we may be able to arrange something.

As far as ADwD is concerned.. better you do it right then to do it badly. I'm sure that there will be a lot of bitching and complaining but thems da brakes. With all the wonderful stuff on the market from Abraham, Lynch, Erikson and the like .. people should have enough to keep them busy until ADwD is fermented and ready to be served.

See you at Borders (STL) and Archon 30! Should be a blast. :)

Abraham, Lynch, Erikson and the like

Not familiar with them....please, do elaborate =)

You know, I just want to say. I appreciate the fact you allow your fans to comments. Your my favorite author and its so nice to see a bit of your outside opinions and a bit of your life as you share it. I totally understand how real life can get in the way of things even if its your career or hobby. I do graphic art and illustrate and sometimes life puts that on hold for other things. I appreciate it all, you inspire me. I anxiously awaiting A DANCE WITH DRAGONS. And even a chance to maybe a chance to be graced by your presence in MN.

comments.upictitle: I'm just your average Thundercats ho': HarleyQ
comments.article:
Holy Canolli! No one but no one seems to *ever* come to Iowa... and now here, YOU will be coming... two days before my *birthday*!! Pardon me while I indulge in a little uncharacteristic SQUEEEEEEEEEEE! ;0)

Phew, that's done with. No squeeeee-s in person, I promise. I'm not that kinda gal!

Anyway, I agree with odclay, above, that you should reconsider your decision not to "baaaaaaa." A chorus of bleating would be more heavenly than Hallelujahs, if you can manage to be convincing. Nothing like hardship to bring people together, right?

As someone who grew up in Anaheim-
Yeah, it does kinda suck.

If this were a realdemocracy, we could propose a bill that anyone in the midst of writing a multi-volume fantasy epic be tax exempt.

Except for Robert Jordan. He doesn't count anymore.

Terry Goodkind would still be responsible for the "raving lunatic" fees.
Why?

comments.upictitle: The great, the knowledgable, the one, the only...: pic#111100213
comments.article: Have fun at World Con. I wish I had the capital to go. I tried to see you in Toronto when Feast came out, but the border patrol wouldn't let us go.

...just now I need to save most of my time and energy for A DANCE WITH DRAGONS...

Good idea.

Even though we don't agree politically I always look forward to seeing what you have to say about the current situation. Often, you've caused me to really think about my stand on things and I appreciate that.
Sorry to hear that the witting isn't going well, however I understand that you've got a lot on your plate...of course I won't pretend that I'm happy about any delay with Dance but I understand it.
I hope you have a nice safe trip to Worldcon and I look forward to reading about your trip both here and on the Brotherhood website.
just wanted to say that your userpic rocks. A lot. I want it on a poster.

You know, though you've probably had about enough of this topic at this point, I thought you might appreciate one chemist's take on the science and science fiction of binary liquid explosives:

http://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/08/17/flying_toilet_terror_labs/

does Parris know you've been blogging this much?

*waves* to Parris: wish I could chain smoke for a night outside the BWb party with you again, but alackaday I'm sitting this one out.

re: the TSA, DoT, NTSB, DoD, NSA, RESPECT, etc; I naturally lean more towards the side of the "it's inconvenient, but DEAL WITH IT!" krewe, but anyone who writes such a spot on cover-blurb about Lies of Locke Lamora deserves my thoughtful consideration of his political views too. I read the Not-blogs, and am now firmly in the undecided camp. Iseult of the White Hands (Lj- "blanchemains") makes a compelling argument for the other side.

Have fun in Albuquerque, and I might show up at that last second.
Please, please, please come to somewhere near Pittsburgh. I heard you read at Vericon a few years back, and would love to have the chance to hear you/see you again. Yeah, I'll admit it, I'm a fanboy.

Didn't know if it came up on the other posts but if you need to find some reading material for your flights you should check out the newest issue of Popular Science (the one with the robots on the cover) they had a big spread about the future of counter-terrorist tech and security stuff, it was really sad to see the lenghts they want to go through to keep us "safe"

The tighter we pull the blanket around our heads the more the light is going to hurt when someone finally pulls it away

Love your books, hope you can make it up to the Northwest again when Dance comes out, i missed the signing in Seattle for Feast

"safe" travels!

I hope your trip fairs well. Even though I'm eager to see the release of ADWD, one can hardly expect an author to stay glued to his writing 24/7. I'm confident that the wait will be worth it and that the finished product will blow everyone's socks off. So don't let the publishers/editors/slavering fans pressure you, 'kay? :D

Speaking of fans...*coughwantstoreadmoreHoundsegmentscough*

Ahem. Had to get that out of my system...*crawls shamefully back into corner*


Anyway. Have a good week. :)
comments.subject: Re: Off to Worldcon

comments.article: which old neighborhood in Chicago, if I could ask...?
Uptown.  See my post of June 30.
comments.subject: Chicago

comments.article:
Thanks for making me giggle this morning with the Sheep comment.

No chance you will be coming over to 'ol blighty anytime soon?
Do you have any plans to tour in a crappy town called Lubbock, Texas? It sucks but I have to live here for a while and it would be really sweet if you popped on by sometime :D

We would really love to see you in Texas, George. Anywhere in Texas would be great. Don't suspect that all Texans are similar to Bush. We keep a watch on your cities and vowed to drive if they were close enough at the time.
My husband introduced your books to me 5 years ago and your character development is extraordinary. Love your blog and all that is said here. Lots of great reading.
Rachel in Austin, Texas.
comments.subject: Texas

comments.article:
Thanks for taking the time to share your politics. I usually hate it when celebrities use their fame to try to sway the masses, but I actually enjoy hearing your opinions. I think that's because you're an intellectual, a writer, someone who survives on social commentary, not an actor or singer. I value your thoughts much more than someone like Shawn Penn or Angelina Jolie (which is to say, I don't respect their opinions at all, actors are just the puppets of writers!). And I've found that I always have something to learn from the older people in our society who have seen and experienced so much more than the rest of us.

So more political rants, please.

-Matt

I'm glad you turned on comments, and a certain amount of idiocy is, unfortunately, to be expected with any blogging comments.

The total # of comments here is crazy. I can't imagine what would happen if you set up a GRRM webcam =/

Obviously a little disappointed you haven't got much ADWD done this month but, hey, it's your life. I'm just glad that I've got something like that to look forward to. As most people have said, I'm quite happy to wait if it's at the quality of your other writing and I'd rather you take your time (and enjoy life!) than slave away unhappily or rush it.
Enjoy the cons, and I look forward (hopefully) to an update in the future when you write that you have had a great month of writing and got more done than you thought. You never know. It could happen.

comments.upictitle: J.A.C.K. Inc.  Super Secret Ninja Force: chiburi
comments.article:
Have a wonderful trip and don't get too bogged down by security.

Thanks for sharing your thoughts on the matter.
Move to Ireland, no taxes for artists, and I believe that includes authors.  Plus it's been a balmy 65 degrees and overcast for the past few weeks!  Doesn't that sound nice?

comments.upictitle: Popular series of fiction, fancy, and fact.: The classic madbard
comments.article:
Anaheim is not L.A.! That would be like saying Dorne is part The Reach!

... Dear god, I am a nerd.
Yes, yes you are.  But I find myself agreeing...

the Brotherhood Without Banners is promising to pull out all the stops this time around.

Including the wine corks, apparently. Which brings us back to your previous point: how are we gonna get those Dornish Reds (or Arbor Golds in my case) home? Can't take them in hand luggage! :p

Anyway, see you in a few days: looking forward to the Cali sunshine (the mist over St Andrews this morning is like a blanket, makes me long for some sun).

Just wrap 'em carefully, stuff a lot of clothes around them, put them in the hold and pray?

See you in L.A. George.*Ahem*...any chance of a new chapter in the reading?:p

Oh, and I second the recommendations above for Abraham and Lynch - very different books, but both excellent.
I'll wrap it in my maester's robe: appropriate! ;)
I hope September proves a more fruitful month for you, and may all our governments not see fit to freak out quite so much!
Gah, my grammar... That's "...see fit not to freak out...", sorry.
